newsitem.title: UK: IBCA raises Daiwa Bank long-term rating.
newsitem.headline: IBCA raises Daiwa Bank long-term rating.

text.p: IBCA, the European credit rating agency, said on Wednesday it had raised Daiwa Bank's long-term rating to BBB plus from BBB and its individual rating to D from D/E.
The short-term rating of A2 and legal rating of 2 are unchanged, IBCA said in a statement.

"The revised ratings reflect more fully the bank's underlying financial condition, although a question mark remains over the longer-term effects of losing its U.S. business and the damage to its reputation," IBCA said.

In November 1995, IBCA lowered Daiwa's long-term and individual ratings following the U.S. regulatory authorities' order to close the bank's operation in the U.S. and the instigation of lawsuits in response to its fraud-related incident at its New York branch.

"This was an unprecedented crisis for Daiwa and led it into merger talks with Sumitomo Bank. The bank also received a Japan, requiring it to reorganise its operations and management systems," IBCA said.

"Since the beginning of this year, there have been important developments: Daiwa's withdrawal from the U.S. was completed by selling its operations to Sumitomo Bank, while the lawsuits were settled through agreement with U.S. prosecutors in February," said IBCA.

"This removed the largest immediate threat of further heavy costs to the bank and Daiwa appears to have survived the period of immediate crisis. Results for financial year 1995/96 indicate its core business," the agency said.
"We understand that the merger talks with Sumitomo have ended and the bank is planning its independent future," IBCA said.
